qas.question: Where can alleles be located in order to be either dominant or recessive?
When paired with any other allele for the same trait, what do dominant alleles give rise to?
When do recessive alleles give rise to their corresponding phenotype?

answers.text: when paired with another copy of the same allele

context: Alleles <a0_0>at a locus<a0_0/> may be dominant or recessive; dominant alleles give rise to <a1_0>their corresponding phenotypes<a1_0/> when paired with any other allele for the same trait, whereas recessive alleles give rise to their corresponding phenotype only <a2_0>when paired with another copy of the same allele<a2_0/>. For example, if the allele specifying tall stems in pea plants is dominant over the allele specifying short stems, then pea plants that inherit one tall allele from one parent and one short allele from the other parent will also have tall stems. Mendel's work demonstrated that alleles assort independently <a3_0>in the production of gametes<a3_0/>, or <a4_0>germ cells<a4_0/>, ensuring variation in the next generation. Although Mendelian inheritance remains a good model for many traits determined by single genes (including a number of well-known genetic disorders) it does not include the physical processes of DNA replication and cell division.
